content.description: Scramble 40' up to the base of the route. From standing on the flake, pull onto the wall and climb past 4 bolts to the crux 5th bolt. Slightly runout moves gain the base of a right angling ramp. Easy moves up the ramp take one to the last bolt. One may belay at the two bolt anchor on the Sloppy Seconds ledge, or continue on the easy crack to the base of Eagle Pinnacle. A single rope reaches from the double bolt anchor.
content.protection:
Bolts, anchors.

Small gear to 2" if going all the way to Eagle Pinnacle.
content.location: Far left side of the lower Eagle Pinnacle wall.  Just left of Sloppy Seconds.

content.description:
I hopped on this but not sure what it is or how hard it is. Someone bolted the arete that Small Affair finishes on. There's one bolt for the belay then mandatory stick clip for bolt #1, no stance to clip a bolt lower.

Apparently, this is an undone project.
content.protection: Draws
content.location: Arete right of Small Affair, one bolt at base to protect the belayer.

content.description: Steep, Difficult 12a climbing to the third bolt leading to a more moderate 5.10 middle section followed by 5.11 climbing at the top.  The second clip is rather serious.  Someone had drilled the first bolt of this route some time ago and then forsook the climb.  We cleaned up the line, finished bolting it and climbed it, thus un-forsaking it.  It is too good to remain abandoned, it's unforsakable.
content.protection: #2 Camelot to gain the first bolt. 5 bolts in total.
content.location: Located between Feeling Groovy and Untickable.

content.description: This was a fun climb with sporty movement on really good holds, but note the flakes holding the pins and any gear you would place are extremely hollow and you probably wouldn't want to fall on them. Would be an excellent route if it got a few bolts.
content.protection: 2 fixed pins and thin gear. Hand size pieces for the gear anchor.
content.location: Route ascends the dark lichen covered face Between spider woman and sloppy seconds and is directly above lichen lovers.

content.description: This bouldery climb has long reaches, small footholds and interesting pinches.  The crux is gaining the Arete.
content.protection: Bolted anchor at the top of Jizz.
content.location: Start at Jizz and move up and left on the vertical face to finish on Spoodge.

content.description: This short route has a number of interesting moves.  The crux is in the first 20 feet, going up a shallow groove and rounded arete.  Easier climbing above takes you to a bolted belay/rappel anchor.
content.protection: one bolt, one fixed pin, and a few pieces of gear (mostly small)

content.description: This excellent face climb follows the arete on the summit block of Eagle Pinnacle.  Traverse over to the start from the right side of Sunkist Face.  The rock is excellent and the moves are really fun.  However, the crux move, 15 feet above a ledge, is totally unprotected.
content.protection: one bolt, and perhaps a tied-off knob

content.description: Exciting route in a great position. Starts on south side of Eagle Pinnacle on sharp arete, 5.8X, at a bolt traverse directly right on good incuts, turn the corner to another bolt and slab up to the top. Couple of bolts on top for the belay. Scramble off the pinnacle.
content.protection: 2 bolts and a small cam.
content.location: South west arete of Eagle Pinnacle

climbs.name: Schmooze
climbs.fa: Bill Leventhal and Bob Gaines, July 1987

content.description:
This short but difficult testpiece climbs the slightly overhanging dihedral just left of the prow of Spoodge.

Some wild stemming is required.
content.protection:
2 bolts and 2 fixed pins.

Belay/rappel from the 2-bolt anchor shared with Spoodge.

content.description: Ok TR, it's in the Vogel and Gaines book. Right side of the Eagle Pinnacle. Pull up to a spike and ride the arete to the top.
content.protection: TR, bolts on top.
content.location: Around corner from Small Affair, not the bolted arete (unknown), the arete further right.

content.description: A pretty good ruote to do after "Ours" on the Sideshow slab. A boulder problem leads to an interesting crack. Boulder problem looks hard, find the undercling ;) There's an old fixed nut to protect the start, a Green C3 pit nicely above it.
content.location: Directly above chains of the second pitch of Ours. Far left side of Eagle Pinnacle.

climbs.name: Rhino Skin
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Patty Kline, Kelly Vaught, and Frank Bentwood, June 2005

content.description:
Climb the slab just left of Finger Lickin' Good past 3 bolts.

The moves past the first 2 bolts will get you crankin' on your fingers (10b/c), and some fancy footwork on the edges is required.

The second bolt is a tough clip, so beware.

The moves above the last bolt involve insecure friction for the feet (10c) until you latch the finishing ledge.
content.protection: 3 bolts, gear to 1.5 inches, 2-bolt anchor shared with Finger Lickin' Good and Goblin.

climbs.name: Razor's Edge
climbs.fa: Jim Wilson, Tobin Sorenson & John Long, 1974

content.description:
Lieback the large, somewhat uninspiring flake system just left of

Electric Razor

(5.11a), passing two bolts near the top where the flake becomes distressingly thin and creaky. When the flake ends step right and climb a steep, thrutchy left-slanting crack system past a wide section to a stance with a bolted anchor.

Bats live inside the flake, so the desired technique while climbing the flake is to thump the flake soundly (enjoy the hollow vibratory sound it makes) and then lieback up a distance. Repeat the process until past the flake and into the crack system.

The climbing on this is fairly good but the creaking flake makes you wonder if you'll make it to the top before it parts company with the cliff and falls earthward. Still, overall it's an experience not to be missed.
content.protection: 2 bolts, gear to 3.5", bolted anchor/rap
content.location:
Located in the middle of the face between Kiss of the Spiderwoman and Electric Razor above a large, low-angled slab. Getting to the base of the climb is somewhat problematic and involves an exposed traverse from the right that comes in below

Spoodge

or climbing a 5.7 thin crack to slab. There's a two bolt anchor at the base of the climb which affords an easy anchor and makes for an easy descent back to the ground.

content.description: Tenuous face climbing along a rounded arete utilizing smears and tiny edges, some of which are quite crispy. Worth doing if in the area and bored.
content.protection: TR (from the Lichen Lovers anchor)
content.location:
Just left of

Lichen Lovers

.

content.description: Second pitch to Electric Razor, technical traverse with a "falling dyno" to a jug on the arete. Pretty reachy.
content.protection: Three bolts, rap anchor.on top.
content.location: Move left off Electric Razor's anchor. First bolt is rusty quarter but isn't totally crucial, crux bolt is good 3/8.but you move pretty far from it to the "falling dyno". Third bolt is unnecessary around the arete.

content.description: After a layback up somewhat loose rock step right onto a steep face and continue up thin edges, then continue up a slab trending left.
content.protection: Bolts and some gear
content.location: This route takes a line up the Pinnacle between The Road to Nowhere and Initiation.

content.description: This thin face route has many small flakes for holds.  The climbing is so-so.  It starts on the ground, to the right of the Tiny Pillars area.
content.protection: 3 bolts to a bolted belay/rappel anchor

climbs.name: Kiss of the Spider Woman
climbs.fa: (TR) Dave Evans and Jim Ivanko, October 1983, First Lead: Bob Gaines, August 1987

content.description:
Interesting stemming and crimping in an obtuse corner.

Bolts are ok but the rock is a little crunchy and the gear on the last part goes in some suspect rock.

Bonus: Undone project? between this and Razor's Edge. Two bolts on it currently.
content.protection: Three bolts plus some cams. Bolted anchor as for Razors Edge or Electric Razor.
content.location: Obtuse corner left of Razor's Edge.

content.description: This is a fun, balancy thin face route with some weird moves.  It's near the right edge of Eagle Pinnacle, to the right of Spoodge.  Follow a line of three bolts up the face.
content.protection: 3 bolts

content.description: Start on the finger crack to the left of Feeling Groovy, when the finger crack ends snake your way past an interesting pocket to gain decent finger holds on a solid, left trending flake feature.  Continue past this straight up to a wild corner and step to the top of a loose spike, then trend left and up.
content.protection: Bolts, finger sized cams to small wires
content.location: Just to the left of Feeling Groovy.

climbs.name: Goblin
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines, Patty Kline, Kelly Vaught, and Frank Bentwood, June 2005

content.description:
Start just right of Finger Lickin' Good with an unprotected face move (5.8) or up the easier crack farther right, to a friction slab with three bolts (5.10a). At the last bolt, you can move left to the 2-bolt anchor.

Falling while making the moves to the first bolt on the upper section would likely be bad and warrants an R rating. However; there is a crack to the right which would likely take gear but might be considered off-route.
content.protection: A few small cams/nuts and 3 draws for the bolts.
content.location: Directly to the right of Finger Lickin' Good.

content.description: This is a fun mostly finger crack on the seldom climbed Lower East Face of Eagle Pinnacle. It's a single pitch but comes in two parts, separated by a small ledge. The first half is a variable width crack/flake with a very loose but easily avoidable block halfway up. Above the ledge, it becomes a perfect, sustained finger crack that eats up pro and jams. The actual crux is probably the first move or two getting off the ground , but the emotional crux is probably somewhere toward the top. Due to the elevated start, be sure to reach up to get some pro in right off the deck. Good fun for the grade, enhanced by late afternoon shade.
content.protection: Pro to 3 inches with a good supply of small to medium stoppers and/or small cams. 2-bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: This is on the far right side of the Lower East Face of Eagle Pinnacle. Unlike many of the Pinnacle routes, which start up higher, this route ascends the bottom slab just above the trail. There are a number of cracks on this slab, but this one is the clean-looking finger crack with a small ledge halfway up. There is a bolt line about ten feet to the left of it. To get to the base of the crack, you need to scramble about ten feet up a small entry slab either ten feet left or right of the crack.

content.description: Tough start followed by a tricky groove/chimney section. Move right at the end to a bolted anchor for P1. Follow easy crack to a ledge and scramble off for P2. First bolt anchor is good to TR Untickable.
content.protection: Up to 3". Tricky and shallow gear in the chimney.
content.location: Groove left of The Untickable, scramble to the start just right of a tree.

climbs.name: Electric Razor
climbs.fa: Scott & Robin Erler, Paul Morrel - Aug 91

content.description: Just to the right of Razor's Edge - the nut/cam anchor has been replaced by bolts. 5 bolts lead up sustained thin edging to connect with the finish of Razor's Edge.
content.protection: 5 bolts, bolted anchor
content.location: Rappel off Razor's Edge.

climbs.name: Eagle's Nest
climbs.fa: FA Chuck and Ellen Wilts, 1970  FFA Mike Graham, Tobin Sorenson, and Bill Antel

content.description: A hand and fist jam widens to an offwidth and then a squeeze chimney.  You can approach the crux pitch by scrambling in (5.0) from the right, or by doing a short 5.7 finger crack.  Above the chimney, easy climbing leads to the top of Eagle Pinnacle.  You can scramble down the back side.
content.protection: gear up through a #4 camalot

content.description: Very thin climbing on crispy micro edges up the middle of the face.  Pretty good actually.  Not sure if it has been climbed before but there were many small flakes that broke while finding a line that was climbable.
content.protection: TR anchors at top for Untickable
content.location: Climb to the first bolt of Untickable then just right and up the middle of the face.  Some very small edges that may clean up or may become unclimbable.

content.description: Starts on very thin flakes to clip a bolt right over a nasty detached flake, not sure how it hasn't fallen out yet, then traverse right across the face past two more bolts and cool hueco features. Third bolt hanger is way loose but bolt itself looks ok. I couldn't finish this as there are zero holds above the third bolt, maybe goes to the arete right?
content.protection: Three bolts, maybe one piece of gear before the first bolt.
content.location: Face left from Andy Dude, behind Eagle Pinnacle.

content.description: This is a clean, arching crack with several tricky sections.  A flared hand crack in the middle of the route is the first hard part, following by strenuous hand and fist jamming above.  The crux is a reach for good holds at the top.  It's at the top of North Gully East, and is obvious once you are there.
content.protection: a wide range of gear, from wired nuts to a #4 camalot

content.description: Starts in a left facing corner, one piece of pro here in the crack, then follows an obvious water streak with three bolts.
content.protection: One smaller cam plus three draws.
content.location: Just left of Finger Lickin' Good, follow obvious water streak to a bolted belay, do Razors Edge for a second Pitch.
